p: There is a huge amount of XPD data in the literature. Previously, XPD results have been obtained using two different techniques. (i) Conventional XPS analyzers in combination with two-axes sample rotation allow scanning large polar angular ranges (typically 0–60°) and full azimuthal scans. This method was pioneered by Fadley and co-workers (Fadley, 1987 ▸, 1992 ▸, 2012 ▸; Winkelmann et al., 2008 ▸), and later used by several other groups ( e.g. Woodruff, 2010 ▸; Osterwalder, 2011 ▸; Fasel et al., 1995 ▸; Shamout et al., 2018 ▸). (ii) Display-type analyzers record 2D patterns in parallel in a large polar angular range of 0–75° without rotation of the sample (see references in Section 2.4 ).
